subSections.text:
{{Han ref|kx=0376.210|dkj=10331|dj=0703.070|hdz=42269.040|uh=5FD7}}

[[Category:CJKV simplified characters which already existed as traditional characters|心士]]

subSections.title: Glyph origin
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{zh-forms|alt=𢖽,𢗍,*誌-partial,*識-partial,痣-partial,䏯-partial}}
From {{och-l|之|to go; to proceed}} + [[endopassive]] suffix ''*-s'', literally “what is being proceeded to” ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|こころざし}}

The {{m|ja|連用形||tr=ren'yōkei|continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|志す||tr=kokorozasu|to intend to do something, to aspire to do something}}.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text:
This is one of only three everyday kanji with a five-[[mora]] reading, and one of only two nouns. The only other kanji with five-mora readings are {{lang|ja|承}}, in the verb {{ja-r|承る|うけたまわる}}, and {{ja-r|詔|みことのり}}. No kanji in common use has a six- or more mora reading.

The unusually long reading is due to two factors: {{ja-r|志|こころざし}} is a nominalization of the verb {{ja-r|志す|こころざす}}, which has a long reading (four [[morae]], ''kokoroza-su''), which itself is a noun-verb compound, {{ja-r|心%指す|こころ%ざす}}. The nominalization absorbs the [[okurigana]], hence increasing the reading by one mora, yielding 4+1=5, or more finely 3+(1+1)=5 (compare common {{ja-r|話|はなし}} 2+1=3, from {{ja-r|話す|はなす}}).
